content:
Here I have the following question: what does mean the notation
f∈F[n]f \in F[n]f∈F[n] on the page 10

so what do mean fff and x1,...,xnx_1,...,x_nx1​,...,xn​ here:
(f,(x1,...,xn))(f,(x_1,...,x_n))(f,(x1​,...,xn​))

So, from where to where f leads/goes and how it is defined ?
And where lives the equation

(f,(x1,...,xn)).σ=(f⋅σ,(xσ(1),...,xσ(n)))(f,(x_1,...,x_n)) . \sigma = (f\cdot \sigma,(x_{\sigma(1)},...,x_{\sigma(n)}))(f,(x1​,...,xn​)).σ=(f⋅σ,(xσ(1)​,...,xσ(n)​))

Also, how did he computed the note on the page 10:
f(x)=∑fnxnn!f(x) = \sum f_n \frac{x^n}{n!}f(x)=∑fn​n!xn​
?

Finally, why has he chosen "/" in this notation
∑n∈NF[n]×Xn/Sn\sum_{n\in\mathbb{N}} F[n] \times X^n / S_n∑n∈N​F[n]×Xn/Sn​
Is it just notation that SnS_nSn​ acts on XnX^nXn without any literal meaning ?

I'd be happy if someone could shed some light into this matter.

When I click on your link I get this message:

Website blocked due to riskware
Website Blocked: docdro.id

v2.6.16 | Riskware: 2.0.202312131448
Malwarebytes Browser Guard blocked this page because it may contain malicious activity.
Warning icon

We strongly recommend you do not continue. You may be putting your safety at risk by visiting this site. For more information, visit Malwarebytes Support.

So, I can't answer all your questions, but when people write something like F[n]×Xn/SnF[n] \times X^n/S_nF[n]×Xn/Sn​ they mean:

  • the symmetric group SnS_nSn​ acts on the set F[n]F[n]F[n]
  • the symmetric group SnS_nSn​ acts on XnX^nXn by permuting the entries of an nnn-tuple in XnX^nXn
  • so the symmetric group SnS_nSn​ acts on F[n]×XnF[n] \times X^nF[n]×Xn
  • so we can take the quotient of the set F[n]×XnF[n] \times X^nF[n]×Xn by this group action and get a new set called F[n]×Xn/SnF[n] \times X^n/S_nF[n]×Xn/Sn​.

Maybe the thing you're missing is the idea of the quotient of a set by a group action. If a group GGG acts on a set XXX, we use X/GX/GX/G to denote the set of orbits, and we call X/GX/GX/G the 'quotient' of XXX by GGG.

I'd assume the reason for the choice "/" specifically is, first of all, it does represent a kind of quotient operation, but mainly it's in order to suggest the analogy with the division (by n!n!n!, which corresponds to the group SnS_nSn​) in the formula for the exponential generating function ∑fnxnn!\sum f_n \frac{x^n}{n!}∑fn​n!xn​.

Here is my new upload without bugs, I hope. The question is as it was before. f∈F[n]f \in F[n]f∈F[n] on the page 10

so what do mean fff and x1,...,xnx_1,...,x_nx1​,...,xn​ here:
(f,(x1,...,xn))(f,(x_1,...,x_n))(f,(x1​,...,xn​))

So, from where to where f leads/goes and how it is defined ?
And where lives the equation

(f,(x1,...,xn)).σ=(f⋅σ,(xσ(1),...,xσ(n)))(f,(x_1,...,x_n)) . \sigma = (f\cdot \sigma,(x_{\sigma(1)},...,x_{\sigma(n)}))(f,(x1​,...,xn​)).σ=(f⋅σ,(xσ(1)​,...,xσ(n)​))

Also, how did he computed the note on the page 10:
f(x)=∑fnxnn!f(x) = \sum f_n \frac{x^n}{n!}f(x)=∑fn​n!xn​
?

Here fff is just an element of the set F[n]F[n]F[n] on which SnS_nSn​ acts. It need not be a function.

In the note, he's pointing out an analogy between analytic functors and formal power series. The analogy can be made formally precise by saying there's a rig (i.e. semiring) homomorphism, from the rig of isomorphism classes of analytic functors (with addition induced by coproduct, and multiplication induced by this convolution product), to the rig of Mac Laurin series whose Mac Laurin coefficients ana_nan​ (appearing in the term anxn/n!a_n x^n/n!an​xn/n!) are natural numbers.
I forgot to say: the Mac Laurin coefficients fnf_nfn​ on page 10 are the cardinalities ∣F[n]∣|F[n]|∣F[n]∣.
@Todd Trimble OK. What is F[n]F[n]F[n] in general and what connection it has with nnn ?

On page 9, we have F:P→SetF: \mathbb{P} \to \mathsf{Set}F:P→Set. This functor maps the object n∈Pn \in \mathbb{P}n∈P to the set F[n]F[n]F[n], I believe. Note that the objects of P\mathbb{P}P are the natural numbers.

I'm not sure if that helps clarify things!

David Egolf is correct. F[n]F[n]F[n] is Joyal's preferred notation for a value of the species FFF at an nnn-element set. Not sure how much you want to hear, but there's a pretty rich literature on species. In many applications, a species (short for "species of structure") gives the set of structures of some type (like a tree structure, or a structure of endofunction, or of a permutation, etc.) that are possible to endow a finite set with, and then permutations of that finite set, say of {1,…,n}\{1, \ldots, n\}{1,…,n} will induce, by "transport of structure", an action of SnS_nSn​ on the set of structures F[n]F[n]F[n].

It's in French, but I think Joyal's original article is still one of the best places to start learning the theory of species. I'm sure others here would be happy to supply references that they like.
@Todd Trimble I just wonder how have they created f(x)=∑fnxnn!f(x) = \sum f_n \frac{x^n}{n!}f(x)=∑fn​n!xn​ ?
I don't understand the question. They (meaning Gambino) just wrote it down! And I don't know what he said about it; I'm only seeing the slides.

But to give some search terms: that formal power series expression for f(x)f(x)f(x) is often called the "exponential generating function", or egf, in cases where we take fnf_nfn​ to be the number of structures of a certain type on an nnn-element set.

For example, in the case of possible ways of linearly ordering an nnn-element set -- the number of them is n!n!n! -- the egf ∑n≥0n!xnn!\sum_{n \geq 0} n! \frac{x^n}{n!}∑n≥0​n!n!xn​ is the power series for 11−x\frac1{1-x}1−x1​. The number of possible necklace structures or cyclic orderings on an nnn-element set is (n−1)!(n-1)!(n−1)!, so there the egf is the power series for −log⁡(1−x)-\log(1-x)−log(1−x).
One good book for learning about egfs is Concrete Mathematics by Graham, Knuth, and Patashnik. Another, I'm told, is generatingfunctionology (I think that's the title).

Oh, I now see what may be puzzling you. There are two instances of the letter fff on page 10, but unless I'm totally confused (I don't think I am), those fff's are referring to totally different things!! The fff appearing on the right is an element of F[n]F[n]F[n]. The fff appearing on the left is an egf. Totally different!
That's an unfortunate clash of notation.

This free book may be easier than Joyal's paper:

  • François Bergeron, Gilbert Labelle, and Pierre Leroux, Introduction to the Theory of Species of Structures.

@Todd Trimble If fff is not a function but just an element of F[n]F[n]F[n] what then does f⋅σf\cdot \sigmaf⋅σ mean in (f,(x1,...,xn)).σ=(f⋅σ,(xσ(1),...,xσ(n)))(f,(x_1,...,x_n)) . \sigma = (f\cdot \sigma,(x_{\sigma(1)},...,x_{\sigma(n)}))(f,(x1​,...,xn​)).σ=(f⋅σ,(xσ(1)​,...,xσ(n)​)) and where does this composition live ?

I'm not sure, but here's my guess in case it is helpful:

  • I think σ\sigmaσ is an element of SnS_nSn​, the symmetric group on nnn elements. That means that σ:n→n\sigma: n \to nσ:n→n is an endomorphism of nnn in P\mathbb{P}P.
  • The functor F:P→SetF: \mathbb{P} \to \mathsf{Set}F:P→Set then provides F(σ):F[n]→F[n]F(\sigma): F[n] \to F[n]F(σ):F[n]→F[n]. FFF provides this information for each σ∈Sn\sigma \in S_nσ∈Sn​, so I think FFF is telling us how SnS_nSn​ acts on F[n]F[n]F[n].
• Consequently, I am guessing that f⋅σf \cdot \sigmaf⋅σ refers to F(σ)(f)∈F[n]F(\sigma)(f) \in F[n]F(σ)(f)∈F[n].

David is correct. (I personally would write F:Pop→SetF: \mathbb{P}^{op} \to \mathsf{Set}F:Pop→Set for a right action, but it doesn't make much difference here since a groupoid like P\mathbb{P}P is isomorphic to its opposite.)

This by the way is not uncommon notation. In group representation theory, a left action of a group GGG on a vector space VVV is commonly denoted using notation like g⋅vg \cdot vg⋅v. What is really meant of course, if the representation is given by a monoid homomorphism ϕ:G→hom⁡(V,V)\phi: G \to \hom(V, V)ϕ:G→hom(V,V), is ϕ(g)(v)\phi(g)(v)ϕ(g)(v). Here we are just extrapolating this notation from the case of a 1-object category (like a group or monoid) to the case of a category with many objects, like P\mathbb{P}P.

F[n]F[n]F[n] is a set with a right action of SnS_nSn​, so when we have f∈F[n]f \in F[n]f∈F[n] and σ∈Sn\sigma \in S_nσ∈Sn​, then σ\sigmaσ can act on the right giving a new element that someone decided to call f⋅σf \cdot \sigmaf⋅σ.
All this is a pretty standard way to talk.
